. It is a major Catholic pilgrimage site that gets more than 10 million visitors per year, mostly coming to visit the
, the second largest Catholic temple in the World.

found a broken terracotta statue of the Virgin Mary at the Paraíba river (likely sculpted in the XVII century). Many local miracles have been attributed to the statue, which in 1734, has been placed in a chapel. The chapel became too small for the amount of visitors that it received, and the construction of a larger church started in 1834.

The village around the chapel was given the name
(female form of "appeared") and became a district of Guaratinguetá in 1842. The statue was given the name
(Our Lady of Aparecida) and the larger church that received the statue, nowadays called

, was finished in 1888.

Aparecida became a municipality in 1928, and one year later, the pope Pio XI declared Our Lady of Aparecida as the patroness of Brazil. The temple that currently hosts the statue of the saint, the
, started being constructed in 1955, being declared a National Sanctuary in 1984.
in the São Paulo state). It can be reached in about 2 hours from São Paulo, and 3 hours from Rio de Janeiro.
Aparecida's closest airport with commercial flights is in
, about 1 hour by car. São José dos Campos has about 2 intercity buses per hour to Aparecida.
There are about 2 intercity buses per hour from São Paulo (2:20 hours trip, R$ 37,30 as of July 2013), operated by
. There may be more frequent buses from cities of the Paraíba valley. Buses from Rio de Janeiro are less frequent (every 2 hours or so), and are operated by

value: Our Lady of Aparecida, one of the main symbols of Catholic faith in
alt=Basílica Nova, Santuário Nacional de Nossa Conceição Aparecida
address=Avenida Dr. Júlio Prestes, s/n - Bairro Ponte Alta

content=Inaugurated in 1980, the huge temple, with a 100-m high tower and an area of 23 thousand square meters, is obviously the main attraction of the city. The temple has the shape of a cross and its architect was Benedito Calixto Filho. The tower contains an observation decks that provides nice views of the city, the Paraíba river, and surrounding region.

content=The terracotta image of Our Lady of Aparecida, declared by the Roman Catholic Church as "Patroness of Brazil" and one of the main symbols of the Catholic faith in the entire country, was originally found decapitated in a river in 1717. Recent studies show that it was likely crafted by Frei Agostinho de Jesus in the XVII century. The characteristic crown and blue cap of the image was given by Princess Isabel of Brazil in 1888.
name=Basílica Velha de Nossa Senhora Aparecida
content=Inagurated in 1888, this Baroque-style church was the previous host of the image of Our Lady of Aparecida. It is generally visited by pilgrims together with the new church.
content=The pedestrian bridge that links the
. It offers nice views of the Basílica Nova and of the city.
content=Catholic seminar in Renaissance-style, constructed in 1894. Also contains a pousada-style hotel.

content=The spot in the Paraíba river where the image of Our Lady of Aparecida was presumably found. The place contains a chapel, some monuments, and a few tourist shops. If that doesn't seem much, one can at least take a scenic photo of the Paraíba river with the Basílica in the background.

content=Unless you are part of a Catholic pilgrimage or you are very adventurous, you will hardly have the chance of visiting this XIX century church, in the middle of the rural area of the municipality and only accessible by dirt roads. The church is last remaining building of the Bonfim village, that disappeared with the decline of coffee farming, and is nowadays a stop point for pilgrims from other parts of the Paraíba valley.
address=Av. Papa João Paulo II (Av. Monumental)
) weekend market, with about 3,500 tents, takes the entire path between the
(intercity bus terminal) and the Basílica de Nossa Senhora Aparecida. Here it is possible to buy practically everything, legal or not, related or not with Catholic faith.
address=Avenida Dr. Júlio Prestes, s/n - Bairro Ponte Alta (Basílica de Nossa Senhora Aparecida)
content=You can buy locally-made bread and cakes at this bakery in the underground of the
. It is a social project, with the products made by low income young people in the region.
